newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: Dutch call money slips, guilder steady versus mark.
newsitem.headline: Dutch call money slips, guilder steady versus mark.

text.p: Dutch call money dipped sharply to trade at 2.56 percent in late Wednesday dealing, coasting lower on an influx of government payments into the money market.
Dealers said social security payments had boosted market liquidity, reducing demand for overnight guilders.
They said call money finished the session at the day's low of 2.56 percent, with most deals having been done between 2.62 and 2.68 percent.
"Rates slipped fractionally earlier this week, but this was the first big dip," a dealer said.
Rates at the long end also came off slightly, with six-month guilders quoting at 2.78 percent bid.
One-year guilders were also down at 3.0 percent bid, influenced by a fall in guilder-bond yields, with dealers reporting reasonable volumes.
The guilder held steady against the mark. The Dutch central bank pegged the currency at 112.065 per 100 marks, unchanged from Tuesday's fixing.
